pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:3.1: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:4.1: 2-8. The training rules on asking for oil/honey/sugar/fish/meat/milk/curds
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:5.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:5.2: … ate curds after asking for them.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:5.4: “How can nuns eat curds after asking for them?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:5.5: Who doesn’t like nice food? Who doesn’t want tasty food?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:6.1: The nuns heard the complaints of those people.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:6.2: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:6.4: “How can the nuns from the group of six eat curds after asking for them?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:6.5: “Is it true, monks, that those nuns do this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:6.8: How can the nuns from the group of six eat curds after asking for them?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:6.9: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:6.10: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:7.1: ‘If a nun asks for curds and then eats them, she must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:7.2: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing which is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:8.1: In this way the Master laid down this training rule for the nuns.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:9.1: Soon afterwards a number of nuns were sick.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:9.2: The nuns who were looking after them asked,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:9.3: “We hope you’re bearing up; we hope you’re getting better?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:9.4: “Previously we ate curds after asking for them, and then we were comfortable.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:9.5: But now that this has been prohibited by the Master, we don’t ask because we’re afraid of wrongdoing. And because of that we’re not comfortable.” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:9.7: “Monks, I allow a sick nun to eat curds after asking for them.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:9.8: And so, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:10.1: ‘If a nun who is not sick asks for (oil … honey … sugar … fish … meat … milk … ) curds and then eats them, she must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:10.2: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing which is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:11.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination by both complete Orders through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:12.2: one who is comfortable without curds.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:13.2: one who is not comfortable without curds.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:14.2: sesame oil, mustard seed oil, honey tree oil, castor oil, oil from tallow.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:15.2: For every mouthful, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:16.1: If she is not sick, and she does not perceive herself as sick, and she eats curds after asking for them, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:16.2: If she is not sick, but she is unsure of it, and she eats curds after asking for them, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:16.3: If she is not sick, but she perceives herself as sick, and she eats curds after asking for them, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:17.1: If she is sick, but she does not perceive herself as sick, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:17.2: If she is sick, but she is unsure if she is, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:17.3: If she is sick, and she perceives herself as sick, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:18.2: if she is the first offender.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:19.1: The eighth training rule entailing acknowledgment is finished.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:20.1: “Venerables, the eight rules on offenses entailing acknowledgment have been recited.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:20.2: In regard to this I ask you,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:20.8: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment in the nuns’ analysis is finished.
